definition: Mencius 孟子 (c. 372-c. 289), Confucian philosopher
first month of a season/eldest amongst brothers
surname Meng
given name of Mencius

Zou Yan (305-240 BC), founder of the School of Yin-Yang of the Warring States Period (475-221 BC)
Yang Zhu (c. 440-360 BC), Chinese philosopher advocating ethical egoism
Yanzi (-c 500 BC), famous statesman from Qi of the Warring States, also known as 晏子, hero of book 晏子春秋
"universal love", principle advocated by Mozi 墨子[Mo4 zi3], stressing that people should care for everyone equally
Rizhilu or Record of daily study, by early Confucian philosopher Gu Yanwu 顧炎武|顾炎武
Classic of Rites (same as 禮記|礼记[Li3 ji4])
so dedicated as to forget one's meals (idiom)
restrain yourself and return to the rites (idiom, from Analects); to subdue self and observe proprieties/(any number of possible translations)
Second Sage, traditional title of Mencius 孟子[Meng4 zi3] in Confucian studies
On learning, classic book by Confucian philosopher Xun Zi 荀子 (c. 310-237 BC)
instructing with tireless zeal (idiom, from Analects)
Aristotle (philosopher)
to plan and consider/to reflect on one's best strategy
Mr Gongyang's Annals or commentary on 春秋[Chun1 qiu1], early history, probably written by multiple authors during Han dynasty, same as 公羊春秋[Gong1 yang2 Chun1 qiu1]
History of Zhou of the Northern Dynasties, twelfth of the 24 dynastic histories 二十四史[Er4 shi2 si4 Shi3], compiled under Linghu Defen 令狐德棻[Ling2 hu2 De2 fen1] in 636 during Tang Dynasty, 50 scrolls
Yang Xiong (53 BC-18 AD), scholar, poet and lexicographer, author of the first Chinese dialect dictionary 方言[Fang1 yan2]
